title: 107_hr2138
content:
The "Bridges to the Cuban People Act of 2001" allows for the export of food and medicines to Cuba, exempting them from trade restrictions. The "Bridges to the Cuban People Act of 2001" exempts the export of agricultural commodities, farm machinery, medicine, and medical devices to Cuba from trade restrictions, with exceptions for goods under export controls or restrictions imposed by the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. The U.S.C. 1702 prohibits or restricts machinery or equipment if it poses a threat to national security due to its technology. This supersedes the Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 and other laws. SEC. 102 of the Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 removes prohibitions on vessels entering US ports if they transport items permitted for export to Cuba. SEC. 103 calls for a study on export promotion and credit programs for Cuba. The Secretary of Agriculture will conduct a study on US agricultural export promotion and credit programs to promote consumption of agricultural commodities in Cuba. A report with study results and recommendations for legislation will be submitted to relevant committees within 90 days of enactment. The Secretary of Agriculture will conduct a study on US agricultural export promotion and credit programs to promote consumption of agricultural commodities in Cuba. A report with study results and recommendations for legislation will be submitted to relevant committees within 90 days of enactment. SEC. 104. REPORT TO CONGRESS.

Within 6 months of this Act's enactment, the President must report to Congress on sales to Cuba of agricultural commodities, farm machinery, medicines, and medical devices. The report will detail the volume and dollar amounts of exports, types of goods exported, and any indications of misuse of medical items.

SEC. 105. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 105. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms such as agricultural commodity, medical device, and medicine. The President shall not regulate or prohibit travel to, from, or within Cuba by US nationals or lawful permanent residents, including transactions incident to such travel. This provision supersedes any other law. Transactions related to travel to or from Cuba, including importation of personal baggage, payment of living expenses, acquisition of goods or services, and arrangement of travel, promotion, or facilitation of travel within Cuba are generally allowed, except as provided in specific cases. Transactions related to travel to, from, or within Cuba, including nonscheduled air, sea, or land voyages, banking transactions, and importation of personal goods, are generally allowed, excluding the importation of certain goods for personal consumption. The importation of goods for personal consumption from Cuba is restricted, except in cases of war, armed hostilities, or credible threats to public health or safety of US nationals. This section applies to presidential actions before the enactment of this Act. The Act repeals certain provisions of law related to trade sanctions and defines terms such as "lawfully admitted for permanent residence" and "national of the United States." The Act defines the term "national of the United States" according to the Immigration and Nationality Act. TITLE III--SCHOLARSHIPS FOR CERTAIN CUBAN NATIONALS

SEC. 301. SCHOLARSHIPS FOR GRADUATE STUDY. The President is authorized to provide scholarships for Cuban nationals for graduate study in various fields. The allocated funds for fiscal years 2002 through 2006 are specified for a limited number of scholarships each year. For fiscal years 2003 to 2006, funds allocated for scholarships for Cuban nationals for graduate study are as follows: $1,750,000 for 25 scholarships in 2003, $2,450,000 for 35 scholarships in 2004, 2005, and 2006. TITLE IV--MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS

SEC. 401. WAIVER AUTHORITY WITH RESPECT TO PUBLIC LAW 104-114.

The President can waive sanctions and restrictions on assistance under Public Law 104-114 to promote democracy in Cuba. The President can also waive grounds of inadmissibility for certain aliens to further the national economic interest of the United States.

SEC. 402. PROHIBITION ON LIMITING ANNUAL REMITTANCES. SEC. 402 prohibits limiting annual remittances to Cuba by individuals under U.S. jurisdiction. The Secretary of the Treasury must rescind regulations that restrict remittance amounts. Prosecution for money laundering offenses is not prohibited. The section defines "covered medical article" as a medicine or medical device of Cuban origin, allows importation into the US as authorized by law, and specifies the term "Secretary" as the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can authorize the importation of Cuban medical articles into the US if there is a medical need not met by other medicines or devices in commercial distribution. The determination of medical need can be made prior to the submission of an application and is not affected by the subsequent distribution of other medicines or devices in the US. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can authorize the importation of Cuban medical articles into the US if they meet the same medical need as other medicines or devices. Criteria for this determination will be established by regulation. SEC. 404 prohibits the use of funds to enforce unilateral sanctions on goods or services meant exclusively for children, except in agreements with other countries.
